headline.main: Children Tossing School Lunch Fruits and Vegetables

docs.abstract: Requiring children to select a fruit or vegetable as part of the school lunch program has not resulted in more consumption of fruits and vegetables.

docs.lead_paragraph: The eat-what-you-kill movement is drawing new converts across the country.

headline.main: Blessed Be My Freshly Slaughtered Dinner
headline.print_headline: Blessed Be My Freshly Slaughtered Dinner

docs.abstract: News Analysis; small but growing number of people in United States are joining eat-what-you-kill movement, which gained widespread attention in 2011 when Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg announced he was engaging in practice; many within movement are members for ethical reasons, and say that they empathize more easily with animals whose meat provides them with meals.
docs.snippet: The eat-what-you-kill movement is drawing new converts across the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: The TV personality on the pornification of cuisine, cooking as an act of self-reliance and why loving food isn’t enough to make you a star.

headline.main: Alton Brown Has Had It With Foodies
headline.print_headline: Alton Brown Has Had It Up to Here With Foodies

docs.abstract: Ana Marie Cox Talk interview with Food Network host Alton Brown, in which he discusses obesity, self-reliance and spiritual importance of sharing food with others.
docs.snippet: The TV personality on the pornification of cuisine, cooking as an act of self-reliance and why loving food isn’t enough to make you a star.

docs.lead_paragraph: Teenagers who spend an extra hour a day surfing the internet, watching TV or playing computer games risk performing two grades worse in exams than their peers who don't, according to research by British scientists.

headline.print_headline: Extra Screen Time Drags Down Teenagers' Exam Grades, Study Finds

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said pure powdered caffeine is “potentially dangerous” and threatened to seize the product if it found violations.

headline.main: F.D.A. Warns 5 Producers of Powdered Caffeine
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Gives Warnings to Producers of Caffeine

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration says it has sent warning notices to five producers of pure powdered caffeine; cites risk of harm and even death posed by powdered substance.
docs.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration said pure powdered caffeine is “potentially dangerous” and threatened to seize the product if it found violations.
